linesOfText.text:
When Wen was a very little girl,
still wearing pants with an open slit,
life held a lot of wonders for her.

She wondered how long she had been
in this world. She wondered if dolls
had feelings the way she did. She
wondered if Baba could use his
fishing net to bring down a star
to replace the light bulb. She
wondered if Mama could cut
a piece of cloud from the sky
to pad her winter coat.

Little Wen had all kinds of
questions, all sorts of ideas, and
actively explored her life as soon
as she opened her eyes.

Grooming, she felt, was a waste
of her time. She would always
run around with messy hair and a
dirty face. Her neighbours called
her “A little mad girl. ”

Little Wen roamed the streets
and climbed trees.

Once, Mama told her: “Only
mischievous boys climb like
monkeys. Girls should not
climb.”

“Why not”

“People say if a girl climbs
trees, her babies will be born
with six toes.”

Little Wen liked that idea.
“That’s good. My baby girls
will climb faster.”

Unlike other girls who were taught to behave, be
quiet, and not ask questions that girls should not
ask, Little Wen lived by her own rules and asked
all sorts of questions. When she was not satisfied
with the answers, Little Wen went into action,
trying to find answers on her own. Neighbours
said that Little Wen lacked proper upbringing.

In Little Wen’s courtyard lived the Dongs,
the Lis, the Mas, and Little Wen’s family—
the Wangs. It was like one big family. When
Little Wen misbehaved, she found four
“Mamas” scolding her.

Auntie Dong said: “You
speak your mind without
thinking. Learn to hold
your tongue.”

Auntie Ma tried to make
Little Wen embroider.
“Needlework will help
keep her still.”

Auntie Li frowned. “She
is all over the place. It is
a disgrace to raise a little
girl like her. Her mama
should discourage her
curious mind before
she gets into serious
trouble.”

In those days, people believed that if a little girl lacked
proper upbringing, when she grew up, she would not
find a suitable husband. So, the ladies took it as their
responsibility to straighten out Little Wen:

“That is not a question a little girl should ask.”

“You are not allowed to talk back to adults.”

“You are not a boy. You cannot behave
like one.”

“Behave yourself like other girls,
and don’t shame your family.”

Little Wen wondered: How
should girls behave?

Other girls Little Wen’s age were quiet, clean, and well
behaved. They all had good reputations. Little Wen
tried to behave, but could not hold herself still for
more than five minutes. She always had questions to
ask.

One day, when Little Wen was trying to sit still like a
good girl, she overheard Auntie Li say: “Her parents
should send her back to where she came from.”

Was she talking about me? Little Wen wondered.
Where did I come from? I want to know!

So Little Wen went to ask her mama. Mama was
mending Little Wen’s new dress, which was
already dirty and torn.

“Mama, where did I come from?”

“Off the tree.”

“No. I don’t mean
today. Where was I
from before that?”

“Off the roof of
Auntie Li’s little
shed, if you mean
yesterday.”

Auntie Li had a little shed for her
stove outside her house. Mama put
Little Wen’s peanut plant on its roof
for better sunlight. Little Wen often
climbed up to check on its growth.

Yesterday, Little Wen climbed
up the roof to check the plant
again. She thought the plant
was growing too slowly. So
she gave it a little lift to help it
grow taller.

To make Mama understand her question, Little
Wen used a fairy tale as an example. “Thumbelina’s
mama got her from a tulip bud. Where did you get
me, I mean, at the very beginning?”

“I peeled you out of an onion,”
Mama said.

“Why an onion, not a flower bud? Onions
sting the eyes and bring tears. Change that.
Tell me you got me from a flower. I like the
flower bud tale better.”

“Thumbelina was a sweet little
girl. But you always bring me
embarrassment and tears.
You were from an onion.”

Mama pulled Little Wen into her
arms and gave her a big kiss.

Little Wen got another idea. “You can
plant an onion the way you plant a
peanut, right? Will you plant me?”

“No, I don’t want another little girl
– just you.”

Remembering to water the
plant, Mama put Little Wen
down, and went to fill the
watering can.

Soon Mama returned, the watering can
still full. “What have you done to the
peanut plant, Little Wen?”

“What?” Little Wen went
out to take a look.

The plant was dead.

“You said you tried to help the plant grow taller. How?
Did you pull it upwards?”

Little Wen nodded her head and felt very bad.

Mama sighed. “Oh, well. You are not
the first one to do such a
foolish thing.”

“There is a Chinese saying — ‘Helping the
shoots grow by pulling them upwards.’ It
means ruining things by being impatient.
Long ago, an eager farmer measured
his crops often, and thought
their growth slow.

So he tugged on his crops to make them
grow faster. Later, all his crops died.”

How interesting! Little Wen
wanted to hear more
Chinese sayings.

One night, Mama was going to wash
Little Wen’s feet in the courtyard.

When Mama put the basin down,
the bright moon in the water
shattered into pieces.
Later, all the pieces
came back together to
form a whole moon again.
That was fascinating!

Little Wen took out the wire strainer
Mama used for scooping up noodles.
She wanted to lift the moon out in one
whole piece.

“No, you cannot do that,” Mama laughed.
“There is no moon in the water, only its
reflection. There is a Chinese saying that
goes with this, too—”

“ ‘Catching the moon in the water,’
which means making an effort for nothing.”
Hey, every time I do something wrong, Mama tells me a
Chinese saying, Little Wen thought.
But...

Sometimes, Little Wen got spanks
instead of Chinese sayings.

In those days, parents spanked their
children to teach them a lesson. Like
the time when Little Wen caused an
enormous embarrassment....

In the old days, there was no kitchen or bathroom in a
house. Each family had a bucket to hold used water.
When the buckets were full, they were taken to a drain
next to the public bathroom, two blocks away.

Sometimes boys were too lazy to run to the public
bathroom. Instead, they peed right into the bucket.

Little Wen asked Mama: “Why do they pee standing up?”

Mama said: “Because they are boys. Girls cannot do that,
so don’t you even think about it.”

Girls cannot do that! Why?
Little Wen’s curiosity got the better of her.

After a boy finished peeing and wandered off,
Little Wen brought some bricks to the bucket.

She held the slit of her pants open, stuck out her
tummy, aimed at the bucket and peed!

“Ai ya!”

“My heavens!”

“Where is Mrs. Wang?”

The ladies shrieked and
called out for Little Wen’s
mama.

Terribly embarrassed,
Mama dashed out and
removed Little Wen,
her pants and shoes
dripping, from the scene.

“Haven’t I told you ‘You cannot do that?’
This time, I will make you remember
it forever!” Mama pulled a stool to the
center of the room, and got out her
feather duster with the bamboo stick
handle. “Bend over!”

Little Wen was shocked. Mama had
never been this angry before. Suddenly
a question popped into her head.
“Wait! Before you spank me for doing
something wrong again, tell me,
what is the Chinese saying for this one?”

Little Wen’s question surprised Mama.
When she realized what Little Wen
meant, she burst into laughter. Mama
laughed and laughed and laughed. At
last, she dropped her bamboo stick, and
gave Little Wen a big hug.

“There is no Chinese saying for that one.
Not yet,” she said, “because there has
never been anyone like you.”

Little Wen and Mama planted another peanut plant.
To make the new plant grow faster, this time
Little Wen fed it a raw egg. And the plant grew
happily ever after.
